Die appèl teen die

Die verhoorhof se afwysing van die aansoek van die. appellant om hom

sections.facts: The appellant, Sipho Mandlasi, aged 22, was charged with the murder of Sipho Mokoena, a black boy aged about five to seven years, who disappeared on 31 January 1985. The child's body was discovered on 1 February 1985 in a bush near a spring, partially concealed in a plastic bag. A post‑mortem could not determine the cause of death because all soft tissues were absent. The State relied heavily on oral confessions made by the appellant on 1 February, before the body was found, in which he described cutting the child's throat with a knife and hiding the corpse. Witnesses including diaken Isaac Maselela, Pastor Mokoena and Chief Pastor John Motshweni corroborated the appellant’s statements, while the appellant’s own testimony was found unreliable.
sections.issues: The appeal raised two principal issues: (1) whether the conviction for murder was safe on the basis of the confessions and supporting witness testimony in the absence of medical proof of cause of death; and (2) whether the trial court erred in refusing to refer the appellant for psychiatric evaluation under sections 78(2) and 79 of the Criminal Procedure Act, i.e., whether there were mitigating mental‑disorder circumstances (versagtende omstandighede) that should have been considered.
sections.principles: The court applied the principle that a conviction must be based on proof beyond reasonable doubt, and that reliable confessions can satisfy this requirement even where forensic evidence is lacking. It also applied the statutory framework governing the referral of accused persons for psychiatric assessment, noting that a reasonable possibility of mental disturbance requires a referral under s 78(2) and s 79, even if medical evidence is unavailable at the time of trial.
sections.application: The appellate court found the witnesses Maselela, Mokoena and Motshweni to be credible and the appellant’s own evidence unreliable, concluding that the confessions were sufficient to establish guilt beyond reasonable doubt. Regarding the mental‑disorder issue, the court noted that the District Surgeon could not assess the appellant’s state at the time of the offence and that there was a reasonable possibility of mental disturbance, obliging the trial court to refer the matter for psychiatric assessment.
sections.conclusion: The appeal against the conviction was dismissed; the appellant’s murder conviction stands. The trial court’s refusal to refer the appellant for psychiatric evaluation was set aside, and the court ordered the trial court to comply with sections 78(2) and 79 of the Criminal Procedure Act by referring the appellant for a psychiatric report and conducting the necessary investigative steps.
